ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic reading comprehension and presentation skills. Exposure to some key foundational texts and methodologies that are the saving grace of the course.
I learned different theories to approaching and writing art history. I practiced presenting and writing about dense, theoretical content.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Not very organized. Not interested in the contents.
No clear feedback, grading felt very arbitrary

The class needs more structure. There needs to be more connection between the readings and class discussions. In-class discussions became extremely dry from such rich readings. This class needs a professor that can strongly guide the students through the ideas of the course, not one who expects the students to be able to lead the class entirely.

Strengths: most of the readings were very interesting. In the weeks that covered art that I had learned in past courses, I re-thinking and criticizing the approaches I assumed were the norm. I think the course has a difficult balance between learning what the reading's overarching theories are and thinking critically about what these theories are missing/not missing. I think returning to works of art to apply the week's theories helped. I also think that it may be good to present on only one or two of the readings each week. Sometimes, there is so much content that it is difficult to analyze the reading and extract the critical approach in every reading.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If super interested in post-colonialist perspectives to analyze artworks, then probably yes.

No, not with this arrangement- I felt that I didnt receive adequate or clear feedback and that grading was arbitrary. It was difficult to understand how we needed to improve/ what we needed to do to improve our grade.
No. Unless you have to take it for the major requirement, please do not take this course. There are way more art history classes that are more interesting and captivating for this class.
Yes- it is required for the major.
